But if you go behind the old, abandoned Whole Foods and walk back behind the hotels which are only occupied annually aside from a few stints in the summertime for family reunions, you'll find an entire bustling community. Within these communities, on these streets, are a handful of apartment complex - situated next to each other carefully like Russian nesting dolls that have been scrupulously, carefully taken apart and set beside each other in a line down the road, piecemeal. The first apartments you come upon are ones which have been on the news for some fairly unsavory dealings, so we won't focus on those too much - appearances, after all, can be deceiving. But the apartments beside that complex, and the two complexes beside that one, are a whole other world that almost no one living in this area knows about. Across from those complexes is a community college's satellite campus - a quiet, sleepy set of buildings standing sentinel beside the road, where students putter in with coffee in hand, yawning at 7 in the morning to begin their sleepy days. The iron gates creak open to admit them one by one, while commuters shake their fists out the window and groan at them for holding up traffic on days attendance is higher. The road t-bones into another residential road, with a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for people who have broken bones in unfortunate circumstances. The treatment center boasts cheerful porch furniture, and a lazily undulating ceiling fan which churns the warm, thick summertime air back and forth. Children run back and forth in the grass at the park across the street, cartwheeling and pinwheeling across the prickly green stalks while bees lazily turn in the flower patches by the road. Old retired folks walk their dogs on the walking path, scowling at the teenagers on their skateboards and nodding demurely at the teenage girls clustered by the playground equipment, gossiping about boys and the latest YouTube sensations. There is a sushi place in a strip mall beside the park that has inexpensive food but never seems too busy - a swimming supply store right beside that, and a nail salon nestled in between. You could fill your pool for the season while getting a manicure and eating hibachi chicken, all at once - the beauty of a strip mall. There is a frozen yogurt place there too, one of the DIY kind, and you often see the teens in the park clutching cold, sweating cups of frozen yogurt covered in toppings while they do stunts on their skateboards and vape because they believe it to be the coolest. The neighborhood in question is a slice of Americana - a piece of history in the sleepy south where hardly anything changes, not even time.
My neighborhood is interesting. Most of the houses are single family, but there are a few homes that have been split into two, while still being attached, if that makes much sense. My home has a small yard in front of it and a small driveway to the left of the house. It, like most of the others, reminds you of a time not so long ago where living in the suburbs was the American dream. This dream at once seemed to embrace the people of this country, but now its pulling away. But my neighborhood and many more still remain, still call out to us and those who visit that the dream is still alive, and we are still holding onto it as best we can. The people don't feel as optomistic as they used to, the upkeep of the little yards are not what they used to be, but there is still a car or two in every driveway, still the youth play as if the world around them was the whole of their existence. The public school that has been here for almost 90 years still stands, still seems conjure a future in today's youth, while stirring up nostalgia in the older residents. The churches are few and far between, mostly empty, but the basketball courts are still full. All of the homes look different, but feel the same. There is a large supermarket called super "A" that has been owned by a large Yemni family, who are quite possible the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The vast majority of the residents are African American. The streets are wide and the kids usually play footbal, only stopping to allow the cars to pass. Most of the people in my neighborhood have been here for generations and most can tell stories of a past where everyone knew everyone. There was a karate school, but when hollywood stopped making karate kid movies, the kids stopped wanting to be the karate kid, so its now a pharmacy, because drugs make everything better, or so I've heard. There is also a small movie theatre that plays old movies at a discounted price, spared from the crowds by the youth's disdane for its lack of just release titles, but favored by the elders, who think it is a small price to pay for a night out, without the kids of course. There is a single expressway that passes through my town. Though the exit and entrance are in the town next to ours. There was once a petition to get and exit for our town. The youth supported it, while the elders refused. It seems that having the expressway in our town would ruin it, so said the elders who eventually persuaded the city council to deny the request. They are building a new highschool, and we are trying to decide on a mascott for our town. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would be then best representation of my town.
Since I live in a large city, my neighborhood is extremely diverse. Residential areas are dispersed, seemingly randomly, between commercial areas, where a variety of businesses are run. Some of these businesses are made up of offices, while others are various stores, restaurants, and places of entertainment. There is no shortage of new restaurants to eat at, or stores to shop in. While some stores are large, well-known, brands that are owned by large corporations, small boutiques are also increasingly popular. They are not only located in various malls, but they also line the streets, which are often in walking distance of neighborhoods that would otherwise be quiet and serene, if not surrounded by so many points of interest. There are also a couple of nearby parks, and I have noticed that people frequent these parks with their young children. Speaking of the people, thereâ€™s actually quite a bit of diversity within my neighborhood. In one small location, we have a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a collection of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Spanning a little further outside of my neighborhood, there are many more individuals of various races and origins, although they are sometimes broken up into their own little communities within the city. We have locations known as Korea town, China town, Little Armenia, and many more, which are only a few miles away. However, only a few miles can prove to be a very lengthy drive. Driving a distance of only 10 miles can sometimes span two hours, due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere, though. While certain locations of interest are inevitably close-by, the city is huge, and people do not generally prefer to commute on foot. As a result, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and it can be difficult to find parking spots just about anywhere. Ironically enough, there has been a great deal of construction in recent years, as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It is seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of even more people moving in, and even more vehicles on the roads. There are many different types of houses in my city, however. Not everyone lives, or wishes to live, in a large apartment building. Residential areas are made up of houses, of various sizes, and smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties contain single-family homes, while others contain duplexes. This is true even within my immediately neighborhood, so there is also no lack of diversity in regards to housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of varying ages, and to be perfectly honest, I am not familiar with the majority of my neighbors. It is not really a tight-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor, and a few other friends from the neighborhood, who were all close to my age.
“Where is everything?” she asked as we drove past the corn fields which filled the horizon. “This is it!” I said, knowing she’d be in shock of the sparseness of the open landscape. She was from a town in which the grocery store was a 5 minute walk from her house--she’d never seen this much open space in her life. Taken back by the ubiquity of corn fields, I shared with her what it was like to grow up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally knew who I was and where I came from. Driving down a two-lane country road, you will reach a quarry which is filled with water. Just past it is the small development I live in. The houses are mostly composed of brick and stucco. All the houses have at least a half an acre of land to themselves which everyone takes pride in maintaining. During springtime, annually planted flowers are abundant along with the midwestern trees that change with every season. The driveways are all filled with the highest end Mercedes Benz luxury cars that glisten in the midday sun after a good, old-fashioned car wash. Continuing along the road toward my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly face. He tends to spend the entire day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over his mower’s hum. Everyone in the neighborhood gets a laugh out of him, but he is always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. He has grown older and has lost some of his wit as he aged. In his past he was a doctor and usually blends in with the grass and his John Deer Zero Turn mower. Finally, you will reach my home. In the side yard, geese are abundant and are chased by our Terrier. Out back, there is a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from the nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. Here was where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to ‘hunting’ animals (which mostly consisted of chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood child available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be painfully brutal, yet there is nothing more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once housed vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers turn into barren skeletons of bark. When blessed with the occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I fought frequently as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We’d build massive igloo-like forts to house our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland was where we played pretend during a time where nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.
transformed_texts: I reside in rural America, specifically in a small Michigan town. Here, you transition from farmlands to quaint tourist towns. There are no large city malls, no Walmart, Target, or even an Applebee's. To go anywhere, you need to drive. Despite this, I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world, surrounded by water. My "city" is encircled by water, with the stunning Lake Michigan on one side and Lake Charlevoix on the other. Wherever you go, you can find a beach to dip your toes in. My neighborhood embodies the concept of a small town. Houses are not crowded together, nor are they identical cookie-cutter homes. They are older homes, some updated and remodeled, others retaining their age. Most homes have full basements visible from the street. Many houses in the neighborhood feature older aluminum siding. The blocks around my house host homes in every imaginable color. Most homes have yards, with trampolines and playsets. Some people have gardens and fences for their pets. These houses reflect Middle America, with hardworking people striving to make a living and either raising families or having raised them. On any given day, you'll see children running up and down the streets. You'll also see people walking dogs, biking, and rollerblading. Neighbors know each other, and you can tell who belongs and who doesn't. You'll see someone grilling outside and waving, or someone walking their dog from a few blocks away smiling pleasantly. The lawns are kept tidy; no leaves are left in piles from fall. Green grass is mowed and well-maintained, and any plants or bushes are neatly trimmed. It's not a neighborhood that impresses with luxury, but one that makes you think it's a good place to raise a family. It's quiet, peaceful, and safe. While it looks average, it excels in representing what people desire—a safe place to call home. Within walking distance, there's the county sheriff's department and jail, with the health department next to it. The city recycling center is nearby, utilized by locals. We have baseball and softball fields where you can hear announcers calling scores and player names. Our small town airport is adjacent, and you can hear the rumble of small planes taking off and landing. You can walk to get ice cream from the local shop, and if you're up for it, you can reach downtown from our neighborhood. My kids can bike to the park just eight blocks away. It's truly a great place to live.

The area where I live can be described as a typical cookie-cutter suburb. In my particular neighborhood, the presence of a homeowner's association is very evident. As you enter, you'll see nothing but well-maintained single-family homes, thanks to the homeowner's association. The front yards are all quite similar, with a small patch of manicured grass, some decorative pebbles, and relatively short driveways. Occasionally, you'll also spot small trees. Each house has a two-car garage. As you drive through the neighborhood, you'll notice newly paved concrete roads. Despite many different families living here, the roads are in excellent condition, with no potholes to be found. Most of the houses are single-story, but sometimes you will see two-story ones too. We don't have the typical mailbox setup you would expect for single-family homes. Instead of individual mailboxes in front of each house, there is a large grouping of mailboxes at the end of the street, like in an apartment complex. Everyone uses a key to access their specific mailbox, and there are two larger lockers for packages. Again, this uniformity is thanks to the HOA. My house is located on the outskirts of a nearby city, so my neighborhood can be described as part rural, part suburb. As a result, we have a lot of land for various uses. There are multiple community pools accessible to anyone living here, which are well-maintained and gated. There are also various walking trails where you can walk your dog or enjoy an evening stroll by yourself. You don't have to visit a park to get your exercise. The neighborhood is large enough that you can run around it for plenty of exercise. Most of the community is made up of retired people, making it a very safe area where everyone looks out for each other. Additionally, there is a small number of middle-aged and young professionals. Regarding the city, it is surprisingly large in terms of population but still has a small-town feel. We have most of the amenities you expect and rely on. For instance, we have exactly one mall. It's not huge, but it serves its purpose. For me, it takes about 15 minutes of driving to reach anywhere significant, but once I do, I am greeted with various stores to choose from. We have everything from high-end grocery stores offering organic food to discount outlets with limited stock and minimal staff to keep costs down. All in all, my neighborhood is safe, well-maintained, and quite typical. We have many nice features, like pools and walking trails. Although we're not right next to any shopping centers, you can easily drive to any major chain store you prefer.

The first time I heard about my place was through a podcast about missing people, which surprised me. Almost every apartment in the area rents for over a thousand dollars a month, yet my friends and I had never heard of such a story. Perhaps it's due to the struggle. I know some of my friends cry themselves to sleep at night. Life is expensive, but we've learned to be thrifty over the years. You start to appreciate the dusty smell of flea market toys and mothballed clothes. As adults, we tend to notice these smells less. You might start smoking or just become too accustomed to the way things are. Yet, the flea market scent lingers. The smell of adulthood is like dusty magazines piled on a closed piano, embedding itself in leather and staying even after washing. Here, three thrift stores are within walking distance. Starting from the far end, you can visit two charity thrift stores, a library, a rare book store, and a curio shop. Downtown is dense, with cars and people filling the streets every morning, but you'd never hear it inside the thrift stores. No matter how many people or cars pass by, the store remains silent. It's a nice place to spend an afternoon. Each year, more people and cars flood the area. It's said to be a developing city, home to one of the largest online empires for e-commerce and delivery, still experiencing growing pains. It reminds me of New York, where everyone and everything is focused on their own goals, and hardly anyone asks much of you. You can be alone, quiet, and independent, and people will leave you be. It's not like the South, where showing concern means you care. Here, you don't pry into anyone's life. You can maintain your shell as long as you like, and the city will ebb and flow like waves on a beach. It's a lively place to be. Between the pianist next door and the two amateur singers upstairs, there's always something happening. In a way, we have less of an apartment of strangers and more of a community of friends. We come together for our needs, celebrate birthdays, mourn funerals, and help each other when we can. In a way, I'm lucky to be here. I quite like most of my neighbors, and they treat me well. I try to keep my space clean, leave them food, and they do the same. I bring them their mail, and they bring mine. It's nice to see them, and I believe they enjoy my company just as much as I enjoy theirs. I live in a massive, dehumanizing modernist sprawl, but it's people like my neighbors who make me feel like I haven't completely ruined my life.

I reside in a small Midwestern town on the edge of a major city's suburbs. My neighborhood, located on the east side of the town, is the most economically disadvantaged area. Property values are low, with most houses rented or owned by low-income individuals. However, it is not unattractive or unpleasant. My neighbors are generally friendly and greet me with a smile when I walk by. Though the crime rate is slightly higher than in other parts of the town, it remains generally low. In the past decade, there have been a few violent crimes within a few blocks of my home, including some shootings and at least one homicide. Last year, our next-door neighbors lost their son to a shooting outside a local bar. Fortunately, apart from occasionally losing items left on our porch, our family has not been directly impacted by crime. Overall, the town has been significantly affected by the "opioid epidemic" in the U.S., with many lives lost to fentanyl overdoses. Thankfully, our town has numerous resources to fight this crisis, including addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training sessions for families and friends of those affected. Despite these challenges, the town has many positives. My son's elementary school has excellent staff, from the principal to the teachers and support staff. Despite having special needs, he has not faced bullying due to the school's positive atmosphere, and he loves it there. We have an active PTO that organizes events throughout the year to promote family involvement and educational progress. With over 20% of the town's population living below the poverty line, the elementary school provides free breakfast and lunch to ensure no child goes hungry. No child or family is treated as "less than" due to an inability to pay, and school fees, supplies, and field trip costs are very reasonable. The City Council and staff have made numerous improvements to the town's appearance, such as repaving roads, landscaping, and renovating city parks. Unfortunately, most of these improvements have been made in the town center and on the west side, where shopping areas and main traffic routes are located. The east side, where I live, tends to be neglected, which is a concern for my community. Overall, I enjoy living in this town. People are generally friendly, the schools are excellent, and there are enough shopping options (both small businesses and larger retailers) to meet my family's needs. Our home may not be worth much, but it is comfortable and sufficient. Our family has resided here for over 16 years, and we cannot imagine living anywhere else.

My neighborhood is rich in culture. It is situated on a hill, surrounded by buildings with historical significance. I live in a seven-story apartment building right across from the old theater, and a block down the hill is a cool little arcade bar where various people gather on warm summer nights. Often, especially on weekends in June and July, you'll see people lining up to get in. A few blocks up is the nearest city park, which is quite large considering the part of town it is in. The park is encircled by concrete, with tall steps built into the wall. During the cold winter months, homeless people set up their tents in neat rows along the sidewalk and the wide steps. It doesn't snow much, but it rains, and the heavy downpours in mid-winter often make it hard to stay warm. Setting up their tents close together in the city center rather than out in the suburbs keeps them warmer. They're also within reasonable walking and transit distance to the only family center for miles, where they can bathe and shower. However, what I love about my city is not just the beauty of its historical nature—the tall, proud buildings, the architecture scattered across the varying levels of hills that stretch towards the ocean. What I love about my neighborhood is the culture of the people themselves. You see, Hilltop once was the most notorious neighborhood on the West Coast for gang violence. Even three decades later, you still hear stories about federal officials and the DEA sweeping through like a broom, trying to clean the streets. The people don't forget. These stories are still passed from generation to generation, reaching newcomers like me, about those days. People work hard, even though it is still considered one of the toughest 'hoods' in the entire city, to keep it clean. They still care about what happens in their city, on their block. They say that if you're white, you shouldn't walk around the Hill after dark. Truly, I believe this warning is reminiscent of the old days, tinged with the bitter taste of social conditioning. Perhaps it's because I am dark enough not to look entirely like a "white girl," or maybe Hilltop recognizes me as one of their own, someone who is keenly aware of the reminders that constantly haunt our nation. Reminders that racism, cultural conditioning, and assumptions are born out of ignorance and fear, even in a city that's supposed to be a cultural melting pot utopia. I know one thing: no matter how far I roam, Hilltop is home. I feel alive walking those streets at night, meeting people who are more likely to offer me a jacket than rob me. It's a place where laundromat owners have stayed open a few minutes later so I could charge my phone when I had nowhere to escape the rain. It's a place where I've sat, thinking myself invisible, huddled against concrete storefronts on the dreariest of nights, only to have someone stop, look me in the eye, hand me a $5 bill, and tell me I'm beautiful and valuable.

I moved to this neighborhood when I was about to start eighth grade. Initially, it was difficult for me to make friends, but eventually, I became close to someone living two houses away and another person on my street. Although they no longer live here, the memories remain. Most of the people who were here when I first moved in are still around. My neighborhood resembles a typical American suburban area, with many two-story houses. On weekends or whenever the weather is warm, I hear kids playing outside. The neighborhood is quiet most of the time. I've never had any issues with the people here. You're left alone unless you need help. I've ordered many packages online, and none have ever been taken from my porch. I feel I can trust my neighbors. There's a park a minute or two from my house, where I have many memories. I used to play basketball, football, and baseball there with other locals. I also had one of my worst memories there when I got elbowed in the nose playing football, but the good memories outweigh the bad. Nowadays, I visit the park to spend time with my cousin's kids. They're much younger and still enjoy swings and slides. Just the thought of going to the park excites them. The park now makes me nostalgic for various reasons. The neighborhood is very diverse, with all kinds of food nearby. Within a mile, you can find Chinese, Indian, Mexican, and Italian restaurants. However, many people now use apps like GrubHub and DoorDash for food delivery. Fast food places are the most popular, but you can find them in almost any suburb. There are also plenty of pizza places. The stores here have everything you need. There are multiple dry cleaners nearby, and on the same street, there's a Walgreens, a CVS, and a Jewel-Osco grocery store, which is popular in the Midwest. Some stores are diverse as well; there's an Indian-owned store if you're in the mood for homemade or ready-made Indian food. Overall, I like my neighborhood. Reading about others' horror stories with their neighbors on social media and the news makes me grateful for mine.

My neighborhood is close to the college I attend, which makes living there quite enjoyable for me. There are mostly apartment buildings, along with a few restaurants and bars that are fun and not too expensive to visit. One of the bars recently changed its name; it's pricier, but the service and drinks are not bad. Most people are friendly. They are either college students or lower-income residents, as the apartments are not very costly. There are many children around because of an elementary school within walking distance of my apartment. I don't know my neighbors and have no desire to; they smoke a lot of marijuana, so the building management placed an air freshener unit right outside their door, which my boyfriend and I find amusing. It's almost insulting. The buildings around me generally look quite old but might have renovated interiors. Down the street, there are new apartments, but I don't like them because I know their construction wasn't particularly good. They're cheaply built but expensive to rent, which I think is a scam, but since they're near campus, the management gets away with it. There's a very cheap restaurant about five minutes from my place that serves food on paper plates and mostly microwaves their dishes. Across from that is a gas station, which I've heard isn't a great place to work. However, thanks to some city funding, the road was redone last summer, providing a nice big sidewalk, plenty of grass in the medians and roadside, making the area a bit nicer. My apartment building is surrounded by trees. Some have been cut down, leaving stumps, but there are still more trees where I live than further down the road. Behind my apartment complex is a treeline and another set of apartments. I live on 42nd Street, but right behind is 43rd Street, which isn't as nice. The sidewalks there are in poor condition, and most buildings look run-down. There are many trees on this street, probably to hide the appearance of the buildings. Most crime in my area occurs at an apartment complex on that street, but I can't blame just them. There are also apartments across the street from me with a lot of crime and a transient population. Yet, I think I like where I live. It's affordable, and there are plenty of useful amenities nearby. I especially like that the university is within walking distance, and there are two bus stops that make it easy for me to get to the store and downtown.

My neighborhood consists of duplexes on a cul-de-sac. They are spaced out to resemble individual houses, with the only difference being that each is painted yellow with white porches and green metal roofs. Almost everyone, though not all, is friendly with each other. Some evenings, we gather at the end of an unplanned driveway to chat while the neighborhood's small children play with their toys, sidewalk chalk, or fly kites. This offers a refreshing escape from the modern, technology-filled world. It feels like stepping back in time. We are surrounded by fields and trees, enhanced by blue skies and white clouds. The downside? This season, we've been experiencing tornado warnings, and for the first time last night, we heard the actual tornado sirens, so we had to seek shelter. Sure enough, you would have found me in my bathtub clutching my smallest dog, along with my purse and a few pillows. My big dog wanted nothing to do with the bathroom and stayed in the living room, nervous and barking due to the unusual situation. The neighborhood was quiet except for the sound of large hail hitting the ground. After the storm, the road steamed from the temperature change, dropping from 92 to 75 degrees in minutes. The hail melted instantly upon hitting the hot pavement. As I looked up at the clearing sky, the sun emerged, and it started to rain. A double rainbow appeared. I rushed inside to grab my camera, quickly snapping pictures to share with my Facebook friends and family. They were amazed, as was I. The streets remained quiet for another hour until people gradually returned home from wherever they were when the storm hit. Then life returned to normal, with moms and kids outside as dinner cooked. This is such a friendly neighborhood for someone who recently moved from NH to NC. I adore the southern accent here. I have a two-bedroom, two-bathroom apartment, like everyone else. Although all the houses look the same outside, not all apartments are the same inside; some are quite small. It doesn't make much sense to me. I love walking along the large field behind where I live and strolling down to the pond, which is not meant for swimming. I've seen deer, and in the morning, you can hear the giant bullfrog singing. It's a fantastic place to live, just forty minutes outside of Charlotte. Each morning, the sound of roosters crowing from nearby farms heralds the start of the day. It's like living in a small village community. We even have a donkey at a nearby farm that brays in the evening to let us know it's there. I feel fortunate to have found this gem of a neighborhood.

Considering that I've been here for about 10 years, I think I can share some of what I know. Initially, when I first moved to this neighborhood, I felt very sad. I relocated from Riverdale to Stockbridge, and I must admit, I cried because I missed and loved them. But my parents wanted the best for me and my little sister, so we moved to a place with better housing and a better high school, where everything was considered "not ghetto" when we arrived. Over the years, I got used to it, made some new friends, and also some new enemies at school. Throughout the years, I never really got to know my neighbors, except for Mr. Glen and his children, as well as Dennis, who lived next to us. They have been wonderful people whom I almost consider family, and I truly appreciate them. I remember when my mom, dad, sister, and I attended Mr. Glen's wedding (they got remarried). It was really fun, and it’s something I look forward to one day, when I build my wealth and give my future wife a queen’s life. When Mr. Glen’s wife, Ms. Veda, removed the small white garter from her leg and tossed it, I caught it! Unfortunately, I didn’t catch the bouquet! We danced the night away, and I had a great time with Marsharii, one of their daughters. However, I haven't seen her since then and hope she's moved on to bigger and better things. The neighborhood itself is like a maze, although now with GPS, I can spend more time exploring it. I've only ventured so far when hanging out with my friends Kason and Curtis. We used to play video games a lot and enjoy life to the fullest. Sometimes I would go to the park and enjoy nature, which soothes my soul and gives me a sense of calm and peace these days. I also bring some sticks I bought from Home Depot to practice my balance, and I bring my bokken wooden sword if I can. I have fun doing what I love. There’s also a basketball and tennis court, although I haven’t played tennis or basketball in a long time, it’s still nice to have in case I want to try again. My dad raised me and my best friend on tennis with Mr. Graves, and we always had a great time. They trained us hard, but we always had fun. I guess there have been many fun times in this neighborhood and plenty of stories, but these are the ones that stood out to me, and I believe the best is yet to come!

My neighborhood is a charming little town. It doesn't particularly stand out from others in South Carolina, but it plays a vital role in the agriculture sector. Johnston is proudly known as the Peach Capital of the World, a title displayed on the town's welcoming sign. The area is mainly farmland, dominated by peach trees and cattle. Houses outside the main town are widely spaced, mostly two-story with either metal roofs to withstand the summer heat or gray shingles. These houses are often set back from the road to allow the front fields to be used for livestock or crops. In the town center, there's a single traffic light at a four-way intersection, where the only stores in town are located. There are three options for "fast food": Hong Kong, a small family-run Chinese restaurant, Fiesta Mexican Restaurant, and Gary's, a small burger chain. A pizzeria once existed but closed recently. Maxwell and Halford Drug is a tiny family-owned pharmacy, known amusingly for their Cherry Coca-Cola. There's a small, expensive grocery store, Independent Grocers Alliance (IGA), which, despite being the only grocery store, sees many opting to travel to a Walmart in Batesburg-Leesville for most of their shopping. Dollar General is the most popular store, offering a wide range of everyday items and staying busy from opening to closing. Possibilities Furniture & More is a tiny furniture store run by a kind, well-known woman in the community. It's been in Johnston for many years and even employs two movers for furniture delivery! Attached to the furniture store is a small pet grooming service, Clark's Cuts and Kennels, offering various services like daycare, boarding, grooming, nail grinding, and bathing. Both a doctor's office and a veterinary clinic are located outside the main town area; they're small but well-equipped to serve Johnston's residents. Johnston Elementary School is the only primary school, and after fifth grade, students must attend middle and high school in a neighboring town. Technically, there are no parks in town, but a 2.5-acre recreational area is being developed to provide more family outing opportunities and attract more visitors or potential residents. Admittedly, there's not much to do here; there are no movie theaters, bowling alleys, hangout spots, playgrounds for kids, pet walking areas, or a wide variety of restaurants. Still, it's a pleasant town, so small you might pass through it in the blink of an eye without even realizing!

I live in a typical suburb in a small southern town in Tennessee. It's a street that connects two state highways, so we experience more traffic than I'd prefer, but apart from that, it's a quiet neighborhood. Not many people move in or out, so I'm familiar with most of the residents. People mostly keep busy with yard work and daily chores. During winter, we sled down a hill on our side street. Our house is at the front corner of the street, allowing us to see everyone who comes and goes, and we recognize the cars around here. Whenever a strange vehicle appears, we usually take notice. Some neighbors go for walks to exercise or walk their dogs. Kids ride their bikes, just as you would expect. We spend a lot of time at home since we work from here. There are four of us: myself, my wife, and our two daughters, aged eleven and fourteen. So I'd say everyone else is used to us coming and going too. We play outside, sometimes even in the rain. Occasionally, we barbecue on our back deck, enjoying the pleasant aroma. It seems someone is always mowing the lawn, and you can hear a lawnmower almost every day from March until around October, when the grass stops growing. Our neighborhood has many trees, as it was originally a wooded area, providing lots of shade, but also plenty of leaves in the fall. So that means raking and burning leaves each year. I enjoy the smell of burning leaves, a nice sign that fall has arrived. Lately, we've experienced little winter, making it feel like an extended fall. Our garage is at the back of our house, so we rarely use the front door unless someone knocks, which is rare. I like working in the garage on my truck or other projects, and when the garage doors are open, I feel more connected to the neighborhood. It's pretty quiet around here during holidays. On Thanksgiving, some neighborhood families have visitors from out of town, and extra cars are parked everywhere. It's the same on other holidays like Mother's Day and Christmas. Overall, I enjoy living here. If it weren't a through street, it would be perfect.

My neighborhood is right in the heart of the high desert, where there's dirt everywhere. Unless someone has actually lived here, they might not truly understand the constant sight of brown, and if you see a lawn, you know that person is spending a lot on its care. When I first lived here in the 90s, houses were widely spaced. Now it's pretty much the same, but with many new developments. Honestly, this place looks more like a city every day, but most places are changing the same way. Most people are very friendly, but like any city, there are good parts and bad. In my neighborhood, I'm surrounded by friendly elderly people, so I guess it's a nicer area. The stores here are mostly chain stores, like Food 4 Less and Smart & Final. If you want upscale stores, you have to travel; I've never really seen any Whole Foods or stores like that. The most prominent jobs in my city, not based on any official demographics, seem to be in construction. I think this is because the city is still not very developed, with plenty of open spaces to build on. That kind of scares me; I like things the way they are now. I left a big city and I'm not eager to return. Speaking of construction, that's the field of my full-time job, as I am a drywall and T-bar installer. What I like about my home is the variety of animals. People come to the high desert for many reasons, especially for the unique beauty of the desert itself. The climate and terrain of the high desert have created challenging ecosystems that need protection and are home to various wildlife. Human residents should take the time to learn about the non-human inhabitants sharing this environment to live safely and harmoniously. My family and I have adapted well to the wildlife. I have three children, and they are all fascinated by lizards and desert bugs. As I write this, they are outside trying to catch different specimens. As for attractions, we have some. Additionally, Victorville is a great place for families to experience the desert. It can offer a unique experience. If you can, plan your visit to coincide with its annual event: the San Bernardino County Fair. This fair will enrich your visit with the right mix of activities and fun the Victorville way. Stop by nearby Wrightwood to see the snow-covered mountains and take some winter sports lessons to round off your visit. Interested in the natural history and culture of the high desert ecosystem? The Victor Valley Museum includes geological and paleontological specimens, Native American artifacts, and historical objects that tell the story of Victorville's societal and industrial development.

When asked to describe my neighborhood, I believe my response is somewhat unique. While others might be homeowners with their own lives, my situation is a bit different. I consider my college campus to be my neighborhood, and the people living in my dormitory to be my community. I also regard the surrounding campus as part of my neighborhood, albeit to a lesser degree. Despite this peculiarity, my neighborhood shares similarities with conventional ones. Like any traditional neighborhood, the one I reside in has houses, people, stores, and parks. Let's start by discussing the "houses" that make up my neighborhood. Before exploring these, it’s important to clarify the types of houses found here. There are three types of housing in my area: apartments, actual houses, and dormitories. First, apartments usually accommodate 2-4 people per room, with about 4-6 rooms per floor. The typical building has two floors, so on average, around 20 people live in each building. Second, there are actual houses available for school-affiliated people to rent, typically 2-4 bedroom setups often housing alumni. However, these houses are less common and spread out due to their inefficiency. Finally, there are the typical dorm rooms housing hundreds of students, usually with two people per room, which is the most common housing type in my neighborhood. With housing covered, let's move on to the people. My school prides itself on diversity, reflected in the makeup of my neighborhood. People from various cultures and ages live here. Most professional staff reside in the neighborhood houses, while new students stay in dormitory housing and older students in apartment-style housing. Simply talking about the people doesn't do justice, so let's move on to the stores and parks. My school is essentially a self-contained neighborhood with numerous stores and a single park. The stores offer dining options found elsewhere along with the school's unique brand of clothing and grocery stores. Thus, everything needed can be found within my neighborhood's boundaries! Additionally, the park is a playground for the diverse residents and is kept clean and crime-free by community members!

There aren't many sidewalks where I live, and everything seems to slope downward. My house sits at the top of the steepest hill in the neighborhood, which people call the "workout hill" because joggers like to run up it for exercise. Since there are no sidewalks on my street, everyone walks on the road. The road is bumpy in some places and feels a bit risky to drive on. Some of the telephone and electric wires around the block look worn and tattered. It rains and storms a lot in our area, so branches and debris often hit the power lines, making the repairs look patchy. There are many tall evergreen trees everywhere you look, but people here dislike them because they block the ocean view. That's why many houses are built high on the hill, with large glass-fronted second stories to overlook the bay. It's beautiful at sunset when the water seems to light up from below and the sky turns orange, though it's usually cloudy, so you often see the sunlight through a haze. Most days are overcast and damp. Moss grows wherever it can: on roofs, cars, and railings. Once, I left my car parked in the driveway for a month, and it turned green and fuzzy with moss, taking me three hours to clean it off. There aren't many children around, although a school is just a few blocks away. Most people in my neighborhood are older, many retired. Instead of kids, people have dogs, which you often see sitting on lawns or racing down the street. If you leave a door or window open, they might sneak into your house. I once found a dog in my living room and had to shoo it out the front door. Rabbits run wild in the area; some are quite large, and gardeners hate them for digging up plant roots and burrowing into lawns. My cats love them, though, and have chased most of them out of our neighborhood. We also have the usual birds, like sparrows and hummingbirds, and occasionally a hawk or eagle flies by until the neighborhood crows chase it off. There aren't any stores nearby, but if you hike downhill to the waterfront, there are a few restaurants serving fresh seafood. There's not much of a beach, but the rocks along the shore are fun to throw into the water. The bay itself is not very wide, and you can clearly see the opposite shore even through the mist on most days.

If you plan to visit Bensonhurst in Brooklyn, you will not find it difficult to get there! Public transport is very convenient and is one of the most popular modes of transportation in New York City. Bensonhurst is quite an urban neighborhood, so you'll still feel like you're in New York City. During your visit, be prepared to see various Asian stores around. Over the past two decades, Bensonhurst has seen an influx of Asian residents. Because of this, you'll find an Asian-owned store on almost every block as you walk. The most popular ones are supermarkets and laundromats. Coincidentally, these businesses are very popular among local residents because the quality of food in the supermarkets is excellent, the prices are cheaper, and it's very convenient. Nearby, there are four Asian supermarkets within a two-minute walk of each other. This adds to the convenience of getting groceries. I'm not saying Bensonhurst is entirely populated by Asian residents, though. It is quite diverse, with immigrants and their first- and second-generation American children living here. Most of the large and popular businesses in the area are Asian-owned. In addition to these Asian businesses, there is a recently renovated park nearby with about ten basketball courts, a large field for soccer or baseball, four handball courts, swings, a children's playground, and even a water fountain for kids to enjoy in the summer. Since we are in New York City, of course, the parks are very diverse. You will see all kinds of diversity here, able to play and get along well. In this neighborhood, there aren't many large corporate buildings. The buildings you'll find are mostly co-op or condominium apartments. Most living spaces here are two-family houses. Most people are quite nice, but very noisy. Every day, you'll hear cars blasting music as they drive by your house, or constantly revving their engines, waking you up in the morning. If you plan to visit at night, you should be cautious. This neighborhood is fairly safe, but people can be unpredictable. You may encounter people who want to cause trouble for no reason, bullies, and thieves. I have been bullied in this neighborhood in the past through physical assault, but that was many years ago. A recent incident involved package theft. Although common, there are package thieves in this neighborhood. Last but not least, although New York City has fines for not cleaning up after dogs, people here don't follow the rules. Every morning, you'll see at least one dog waste on your way to the train station or supermarket. My biggest annoyance is dog waste on the ground everywhere I go in this neighborhood. Be careful and keep your shoes clean!

The first thing to grasp about Portland, Oregon is the concept of "weird." The unofficial town motto, "Keep Portland Weird," is prominently displayed on a building that doubles as a pizza place, bar, music venue, and strip club, pushing legal boundaries in at least half of these ventures. For some, this phrase is a small reminder of Portland in the 90s and early 2000s, a time when the city was lesser-known and less costly, fostering creative and unique subcultures. For others, it serves as an invitation—come to Portland, where being called weird is now a compliment. Despite the influx of wealthy Californians and the ongoing construction of condos to house them, Portland remains weird. Weird doesn't always mean accepting, but it does mean being open to things typically unaccepted. Weird doesn't imply a lack of modern conveniences or struggles. Like the rest of the nation, we purchase most of our goods from China. There are countless ways to be weird, to be unconventional, yet Portland has its share of normalcy. The city has yoga, hipsters, and business professionals. Perhaps being weird means we just take all of this a bit less seriously. In my neighborhood, as in many around Portland, we have colorful homes, gardens with flowers, herbs, and vegetables lining the streets, and free boxes in the summer. Free boxes, often cardboard boxes filled with items someone is discarding, can also be plastic bags or containers. They often hold something magical, a perfect treasure for a passerby, surprisingly often. Free boxes usually contain clothes and books but can hold anything. The magical potential of walking through a Southeast Portland neighborhood captures the essence of Portland. At least, that’s what Portland means to me, but I am just one type of weird among many. Some residents here wouldn't dream of picking clothes from a box on the sidewalk. Instead, they might go to goat yoga (yes, yoga with actual goats) or attend Timbers matches (the city's soccer team). Portland is full of people who love a wide variety of things. It's full of those who chase dreams, or dream about chasing them while spending too much time in bars. Yes, Portland has a drug problem. These issues are often rooted in mental health, and the relentless rain and gloomy clouds for much of the year seem to contribute. Portland also has a homelessness issue, one that no one seems to have a solution for. The homeless population is drawn by the social services offered here, better than in most parts of the country, but still inadequate, as is the case nationwide. The non-homeless population fluctuates between compassion and resentment. In this regard, we're not weird at all.

The mountains always stand in the north, witnessing the sun's journey at every dawn and dusk. Regardless of how much I forget them or get caught up in work and life, they remain steadfast and unmoved by life's challenges. On days when I am most stressed, they demand my attention, and when I turn to them, they offer solace to my anxious soul, lending me strength to carry on, one day at a time. When I first moved here for my undergraduate studies, it was the mountains to the north of the campus that initially captivated me. While the university boasts stunning sights in its buildings, ponds, and trees, which also hold a special place in my heart, it is the mountains that truly reign supreme. The rest of the town has its own charm, with countless cafés where I spent hours fueled by caffeine. One can walk or take the bus to the downtown area, enveloped by the aura of antiquity from the faded colored bricks lining the restaurants and office buildings. Here, this seemingly suburban town shows as much bustle and vigor as its neighboring city. Yet, this does not last for many blocks, as one can quickly escape back to the serene small town atmosphere by passing the library. The contrast of atmospheres in such close proximity gives this city a wondrous vibe, as if inviting exploration. It is easy to create many cherished memories, each associated with a part of the town. Whether it's walking past the rusted swings in the park with friends after an all-nighter or rushing through the busy downtown to catch a movie at the fancy theater for which the university provided tickets. Alas, it is also home to many harsh memories, as all places in life inevitably are. The ponds, in particular, serve as fitting places for reflection or crying sessions at two in the morning during an existential crisis, the latter being something I have more experience with. Observing the turtles, ducks, and insects living their lives, each with a role or contribution, I couldn't help but ponder my own sense of purpose while navigating this mystery called life. So, I walked past the pond, the park, and the suburban houses until I reached a main street. It was then that the sun shone brilliantly over the palm trees, painting the sky, and as I looked up at the sunrise, I realized I was walking north. Sure enough, they were there, as they had always been. The towering mountains touched the hazy blue and yellow sky more than any building on the horizon, and as if speaking without words, they stirred in me a sense of perseverance.

At first glance, you might overlook it—after all, it's a residential area behind a shopping zone, not a place where one usually thinks people live. At least, not where most people would choose to live. However, if you head behind the abandoned Whole Foods and pass the hotels that are only occupied during summer family reunions, you'll discover a thriving community. Within these streets are several apartment complexes, arranged with care like meticulously dismantled Russian nesting dolls set in a line along the road. The first apartments you encounter have been in the news for unsavory dealings, so we won't dwell on them too much—appearances can be deceiving. Yet, the apartments next to that complex, and the two beside it, are part of an almost unknown world. Across from these complexes is a satellite campus of a community college—quiet buildings standing watch by the road where students arrive with coffee in hand, yawning at 7 AM to start their sleepy days. The iron gates creak open to let them in one by one, while commuters shake their fists out the window, grumbling when traffic gets worse on busier days. This road intersects another residential street, with a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for those recovering from unfortunate accidents on the other. The center features cheerful porch furniture and a lazily spinning ceiling fan that stirs the warm, thick summer air. Children run back and forth in the grass at the park across the street, doing cartwheels and spins among the prickly green blades, while bees lazily hover over flowers by the road. Retired folks walk their dogs on the path, frowning at teenagers on skateboards and nodding politely at teenage girls gathered by the playground, gossiping about boys and the latest YouTube stars. In the strip mall next to the park, there's a sushi place with affordable food that never seems too busy—a swim supply store right beside it, and a nail salon nestled in between. You could fill your pool for the season, get a manicure, and eat hibachi chicken all at once—the convenience of a strip mall. There's also a DIY frozen yogurt place there, and you often see teens in the park with cups of cold, sweating frozen yogurt covered in toppings, doing stunts on their skateboards and vaping, thinking it's the coolest. This neighborhood is a slice of Americana—a piece of history in the sleepy South where hardly anything changes, not even time.

My neighborhood is quite fascinating. Most of the houses are single-family homes, but some have been split into two while still being attached, if that makes sense. My home has a small yard in front and a driveway on the left side. Like many others, it reminds you of a not-so-distant past when living in the suburbs was the American dream. This dream once seemed to embrace the people of this country, but now it’s slipping away. Yet, my neighborhood and many others still stand, still call out to us and visitors that the dream is still alive, and we hold onto it as best as we can. People aren't as optimistic as they once were, and the upkeep of small yards isn't what it used to be, but each driveway still has a car or two, and the youth continue to play as if the world around them was their entire existence. The public school here, almost 90 years old, still stands, conjuring a future for today’s youth while stirring nostalgia in older residents. The churches are few and mostly empty, but the basketball courts remain bustling. All the homes look different but feel the same. There is a large supermarket called Super "A," owned by a large Yemeni family, possibly the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The majority of residents are African American. The streets are wide, and kids usually play football, only stopping to let cars pass. Most people in my neighborhood have been here for generations and can tell stories of a time when everyone knew each other. There was a karate school, but when Hollywood stopped making Karate Kid movies, kids stopped wanting to be the Karate Kid, so now it’s a pharmacy because drugs supposedly fix everything, or so I’ve heard. There's also a small movie theater that shows old movies at a discount, avoided by the youth for its lack of new releases but favored by the elders, who think it's a small price for a night out, without children, of course. An expressway passes through my town, though the exits are in the town next to ours. There was once a petition for an exit for our town. The youth supported it, while the elders opposed it. The elders, who eventually persuaded the city council to deny the request, argued that having the expressway would ruin our town. They are building a new high school, and we are deciding on a mascot for our town. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would best represent my town.

Since I reside in a big city, my neighborhood is very diverse. Residential areas are scattered seemingly at random among commercial zones, where various businesses operate. Some of these businesses are offices, while others are shops, restaurants, and entertainment venues. There is no shortage of new places to eat or shop. While some stores are large, well-known brands owned by big corporations, small boutiques are also gaining popularity. They are located not only in malls but also along streets, often within walking distance of neighborhoods that would otherwise be quiet if not surrounded by so many attractions. There are a few nearby parks, and I have noticed people often visit them with their young children. Speaking of people, there is quite a bit of diversity in my neighborhood. In a small area, we have a significant LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and groups of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Beyond my neighborhood, there are many more people of different races and backgrounds, although they sometimes form their own small communities within the city. We have areas known as Korea Town, China Town, Little Armenia, and more, just a few miles away. However, even a short distance can take a long time to drive. A 10-mile drive can sometimes take two hours due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere. While some places of interest are nearby, the city is vast, and people generally do not prefer to walk. As a result, we have some of the worst traffic globally, and finding parking can be difficult. Ironically, there has been extensive construction recently, with large apartment buildings being added to the city. It seems to be a popular place, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of more people moving in and more cars on the roads. However, there are many types of houses in my city. Not everyone lives or wants to live in a large apartment building. Residential areas consist of houses of various sizes, smaller apartment buildings, and condos. Some properties have single-family homes, while others have duplexes. This is true even in my immediate neighborhood, so there is no lack of housing diversity. Similarly, the neighborhood consists of people of various ages, and to be honest, I don't know most of my neighbors. It's not a close-knit community these days, though I have many childhood memories of playing outside with my next-door neighbor and a few other friends from the neighborhood who were all my age.

"Where is everything?" she asked as we drove past the cornfields stretching across the horizon. "This is it!" I replied, knowing she would be shocked by the vast openness of the landscape. She was from a town where the grocery store was just a five-minute walk from her home—she had never seen so much open space in her life. Surprised by the ubiquity of cornfields, I shared with her what it was like growing up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally understood who I was and where I came from. Driving down a two-lane country road, you reach a quarry filled with water. Just beyond is the small development where I live. The houses are mostly made of brick and stucco. Each house has at least half an acre of land, which everyone takes pride in maintaining. In spring, annual flowers are abundant, alongside Midwestern trees that change with every season. The driveways are filled with high-end Mercedes-Benz luxury cars glistening in the midday sun after an old-fashioned car wash. Continuing down the road toward my gray stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly face. He spends the whole day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over the hum of his mower. Everyone in the neighborhood gets a laugh from him, but he is always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. He has aged and lost some of his sharpness over time. In his past, he was a doctor and often blends in with the grass and his John Deere Zero Turn mower. Finally, you will reach my home. In the side yard, geese are abundant and chased by our Terrier. Out back, there is a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional "moo" from nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. This is where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to 'hunting' animals (mostly chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood child available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be painfully harsh, yet there is nothing more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once held vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers turn into barren skeletal branches. When blessed with occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I fought frequently as kids, and during winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We'd build massive igloo-like forts to house our arsenal, usually with branches. In our own little wonderland, we played make-believe during a time when nothing else mattered. We were just carefree kids.

original_texts:
I live in Rural America, specifically small town Michigan. Where you go from farmland to small tourist cities. There is no big city malls, no Wal-mart, Target, or even an Applebee’s. Anywhere you need to go, you have to drive to get to. Despite that I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world surrounded by water. My “city” is surrounded by water. Beautiful Lake Michigan to one side, and Lake Charlevoix on the other. Everywhere you go you can find a beach to dip your toes in. My neighborhood, reflects the idea of small town. Houses are not stacked upon one another. They aren’t cookie cutter houses that are built the same. They are older homes, some of them being updated and remodeled some of them being older. Most homes have basements. Full Basements that you can see from the road. Many houses in the neighborhood have older aluminum siding. We have houses every color you can imagine in the blocks that surround my house. Most of the houses have yards. Yards with trampolines, and playsets. Some people have gardens, and fences for their animals. The houses resemble Middle America. Hard working people who work to make a living and are either raising families or have raised families. On any given day you will see kids running up and down the streets. You will also see people walking dogs, biking and rollerblading. Neighbors know neighbors and you can recognize who fits in and who doesn’t belong. You will see someone grilling outside and wave, or even someone that is walking their dog from a few blocks down and smile pleasantly. The lawns are kept in decent condition. Nobody has leaves piled up from fall time. Green grass is kept mowed and under control. If people have plants and bushes in their yards they are kept trimmed down. It isn’t a beautiful neighborhood that you drive into and think wow look at the nice homes, but one you drive into and think you can tell this would be a good place to raise a family. It’s quiet, peaceful and, and safe. While only average looking, it is exceptional for the fact that it represents what people want in the world, which is a safe place to land at the end of the day. Within walking distance there is the county sheriff’s department and jail. The Health department is just next to that. The city recycling center sits just down the road, and neighbors and residents from around the city utilize the services they provide. We have baseball and softball fields nearby where you can hear the announcers keeping score and calling the names of players. Our small town airport is next to that. You can be playing outside, or even inside and hear the rumbles of small engine planes taking off and landing. You can walk to get ice cream from the local ice cream place, and if you are really into it you can make it downtown from our neighborhood of homes. My kids can ride their bikes to the park which is only 8 blocks or so away. It is a really great place to live.
The general area in which I live in can be described as your typical cookie cutter suburbia. For my neighborhood in particular, the presence of a homeowner's association is very apparent. Upon entering, you'll see nothing but well-maintained single family homes, which we can thank the homeowner's association for. The front yards are all very similar. There's a small patch of landscaped grass, some decorative pebbles, and rather short driveways. Every so often you'll see small trees as well. Everyone has a two car garage. As you continue to drive along throughout the neighborhood you'll see newly paved concrete. Despite many different families living here, the roads are in excellent condition. You won't find any potholes or anything like that here. Most of the houses are single story, but sometimes you'll see two stories as well. We don't have a typical mailbox set-up that you would expect for single family homes. There are no individual mailboxes in front of each house. Instead, it's more like apartments where there are a large grouping of mailboxes at the end of the street. Everyone uses a key to gain access their specific mailbox. And there's two larger lockers for packages. Again, you can thank the HOA and their obsession with uniformity for this. The location of my house is on the extreme edge of the nearby city, so my neighborhood can be described as part rural, part suburbs. As a result, we have a lot of land for, well, everything. There's multiple community pools to which anyone living here can access. It's well maintained and gated. And then there are various walking trails where you can walk your dog, or just go for an evening stroll by yourself. You don't have to visit a park to get your exercise in. The neighborhood is large enough that you can simply run around it and get more than enough exercise. Most of the community is made up of retired people. It's a very safe area, and everyone looks out for one another. Mixed in with that, we have a small amount of middle aged and young professionals too. In regards to the city, it's surprisingly large - at least by population - but also has a small time town feel. We have the vast majority of amenities that you come to expect and rely on. For example, we have a exactly one mall. It's not huge, but it gets the job done. For me, it takes around 15 minutes of driving to get anywhere significant, but once I do that, I am greeted with many different stores to choose from. We have everything from high end grocery stores where you can get organic food, to bargain outlets that only stock a small selection of items and has bare minimum staff to keep costs down. All in all, my neighborhood is safe, well-maintained, and pretty typical. We have a lot of nice things, like pools and walking trails. And although we aren't right next door to any sort of shopping, you can just hop in a car and go to any major chain that you'd like.
The first time I'd heard of my place, I was listening to a podcast about people who'd gone missing. It was a little surprising. Almost every apartment in the area was going for over a thousand dollars a month. I'd never heard anything about that story and neither had any of my friends. Maybe it's the struggle. I know a few of my friends cry themselves to sleep at night. Things are expensive, but we've learned how to be frugal over the years. You start to like the dusty smell of flea market toys and mothballed clothes. You smell a lot less in adulthood. You might start to smoke, or you might just be too accustomed to the state of things. But the flea market always asserts itself. The smell of adulthood is dusty magazines stacked on a closed piano. It wedges itself in the leather and stays in even after you wash it. Here, there're 3 thrift stores in walking distance. If you start on the far side, you can patronize two charity thrifts, a library, a rare book store, and a curio shop. Downtown is dense, cars and people fill the streets every morning, but you'd never hear it in the thrifts. No matter how many people or cars pass by, the store is silent. It's a nice place to lose an afternoon. Every year, there's more and more of those. Cars and people flood it. It's a developing city, they say. Headquartering one of the largest online empires for e-commerce and delivery, it's still showing growing pains. It reminds me of New York. Everything and everyone is set on their own goals, and there isn't a whole lot anyone asks from you. You can be alone, quiet, and independent, and people will leave you alone. It's not like the South, where being a little concerned means you care. You don't pry into anyone's life here, really. You can keep up your shell as long as you'd like, and the city will crash and roll back like waves on the beach. It's a lively place to be. Between the pianist next door and the two amateur vocalists upstairs, there's always something going on. In a way, we have less of an apartment of strangers and more a community of friends. We come together for our needs, celebrate birthdays, mourn funerals, and help each other when we can. In a way, I'm lucky to be here. I quite like most of my neighbors and they treat me pretty well. I try to make sure to clean after myself and leave them food and they do the same in kind. I bring mail to them and they to me. It's nice to see them and I believe they enjoy my presence as much as I do theirs. I live in a massive, dehumanizing modernist sprawl but it's people like my neighbors that make me feel like I didn't totally ruin my life.
I live in a small Midwestern town that is just outside the suburban areas of a major city. My immediate neighborhood, on the east side of the town, could be described as the most economically disadvantaged area of the town. Property values are low, with most houses being rented to or owned by low-income individuals. However, it is not unattractive or unpleasant. My neighbors are generally friendly people who will smile and say hello when I walk down the street. Crime rates, while slightly higher than other parts of town, are still generally low. There have been a few violent crimes in the past ten years within a few blocks of my home, including a few shootings and at least one homicide. Our next door neighbors lost their son in a shooting outside an area bar last year. Fortunately, our family has not been directly affected by crime other than having an occasional item disappear from our porch if we forget to bring it inside. In general, the town in which I live has been profoundly affected by the “opioid epidemic” that has affected many parts of the United States. Many lives have been lost due to fentanyl overdoses. Fortunately, there are many resources in my town to combat this epidemic, including several addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training sessions for families and friends of those affected by addiction. Despite these challenges, this town has many positive attributes. My son’s elementary school has excellent staff, from the principal to the teachers and support staff. Despite having special needs, he has not faced any bullying thus far due to the incredibly positive atmosphere of the school, and he loves it there. We have an active PTO that plans multiple events throughout the year to promote family involvement and educational progress. Because over 20% of our town’s population lives below the poverty level, the elementary school provides free breakfast and lunch to all students, so that no child ever has to go hungry. No child or family is treated as “less than” due to an inability to pay, and costs for school fees, supplies, and field trips are very reasonable. The City Council and staff have made many improvements to the appearance of our town, including repaving roads, landscaping, and refurbishing city parks. Unfortunately, most of these improvements have taken place in the center of town and on the west side, where all of the shopping areas are located and most of the traffic passes through. The east side where I live tends to be neglected, which is a point of contention for those in my neighborhood. Overall, I do enjoy living in this town. People are generally friendly, the schools are great, there are enough shopping options (both small businesses and larger retail stores) to meet my family’s needs, and our home may not be worth much, but it is comfortable and adequate. Our family has lived here for over 16 years, and we cannot imagine living anywhere else.
My neighborhood is full of culture. It's set upon a hill, surrounded by buildings with historical meaning. I live in a 7 story apartment building right across from the old live Theater, and a block down The Hill, is this cool little arcade bar that different types of people flock to on warm summer nights. Often times, especially on the weekends in June and July, you will see a line of people waiting to get in. A few blocks up is the nearest city park. It's pretty big considering the part of town it sits in. Encircling the park is concrete, with tall stairs poured into the wall. During the frigid winter months, homeless people set their tents up in neat little rows along the sidewalk and along the wide steps. It doesn't snow much, but it rains, and the torrential down pour in the mid-winter months often tends to make it difficult to keep warm. Setting their tents up close together, in the center of town rather than out in the jungle, keeps them much warmer. They're also within reasonable walking and transit distance to the only family center for miles, where they can bathe and shower. What I love about my city though, isn't the beauty of the historic nature- the tall proud buildings, the architecture that is spattered through-out the varying levels of the hills that roll down towards the ocean. What I love about my neighborhood is the culture of the people themselves. You see, Hilltop once was the most notorious neighborhood on the West Coast for gang violence. You still hear stories, even three decades later, about the federal government officials and the DEA sweeping through like a broom, trying to clean the streets. The people, they don't forget. Stories are still passed from generation to generation, on through to transplants like me, of those days. The people work hard, even though it's still considered one of the rougher 'hoods' in the entire city, to keep it cleaned up. They still care about what goes on in their city, on their block. They say that if you're white, you shouldn't walk around the Hill after dark. Truly, I believe that this warning is reminiscent of the old days, and it is tinged with the sour taste of social conditioning. Perhaps it is that I am just dark enough to pass for a not entirely "white-girl," or maybe Hilltop recognizes me as one of their own, someone who is just as painfully aware of the reminders that constantly plague our nation. Reminders that racism, cultural conditioning, and assumptions are made out of ignorance and fear, even in a city that is supposed to be a cultural melting pot Utopia. I know one thing: no matter how far I roam, the Hilltop is home. I feel alive walking those streets at night, meeting people who have more quickly and rarely nefariously offered me a jacket than to rob me. It's a place where laundromat owners have stayed open just a few minutes later so I could charge my phone when I had no where to escape from the rain. It's a place where I have sat, believe myself to be invisible, huddled against concrete store fronts on the most grey dreary of nights, only to have someone stop and look me in the eye, hand me a $5, and tell me I'm beautiful and valuable.
I moved to this neighborhood just when I was about to start eighth grade. It was hard for me to make friends at first, but I ended up getting close to someone who lives two houses down from me and another guy that lives on my street. Neither of them lives there anymore but the memories are still there. The same people who lived here when I first moved here are still here for the most part. My neighborhood is pretty similar to your average American suburban neighborhood. The neighborhood has a lot of two-story houses in it. Every weekend or just whenever it is warm outside I hear the kids playing outside. The neighborhood is quiet most days of the week. I have never had a problem with any of the people in the neighborhood. You are left alone in this neighborhood unless you need help. I have ordered multiple packages online and have never gotten a package snatched off of my porch. I feel like I can trust my neighbors. There is a park a minute or two away from my house. I have a lot of memories there. I have played basketball, football, and baseball there with the other guys in the neighborhood before. I also ended up with one of my worst memories there when I got elbowed in the nose playing football, but the good memories outweigh the bad. Nowadays, whenever I go to that park it is to spend time with my cousin's kids. They are much younger than me and still like playing on swings and slides and all of that type of stuff. Just the thought of going to the park makes them excited. The park makes me very nostalgic for a number of different reasons now. The neighborhood is very diverse.
